instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.DDRREG_EN: What is DDRREG_EN? DDRREG_EN is an enable signal that turns on power rails for DDR memory.
definitions.P1V5S0_EN: What is P1V5S0_EN? P1V5S0_EN is an enable signal that turns on the PP1V5_S0 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS0_EN_L: What is P5VS0_EN_L? P5VS0_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S0 5v power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message:
Hello. This is my first post on this forum :)


I have a macbook air 13 "it will not boot.
   
  it shows green light in mega safe, but it won`t start up. (Not change to orange when battery is connected)
   
  (I`am not an expert have never repaired LB before, but wish to learn)
  
 
  For power up <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> i need:
   
  1)<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_S5_S5</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=18.5V
   
  2)<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=8.4V
   
  3)<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_ISNS</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=8.4V
   
  4)<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=3.42V
   
  5)<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  VOLTAGE=3.3V
   
  Right?
   
  I don`t have to check all components on same circuits?
   
  What I have on the circuits are:
   
  1) <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_S5_S5</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=3D16.7V OK
   
  2) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=3D8.4V  OK
   
  3) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_ISNS</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=3D8.4V OK
   
  4) <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> VOLTAGE=3D3.42V OK
   
  5) <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  VOLTAGE= 0.33V NOT OK! 
  
Do I have to measure all the S5 S3 ENET S0 lines to?
   
  Tank you for answer me and help :)

 
   
  Regards, 
   
  Glenn

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message:
Check for short on this rail:
Diode Mode - red on GND & black on rail.

If there is no short look at <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>:
- check VIN-Pin23
- check EN-Pin21

what do you measure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message:
Measure L7260 in diode mode (->+) with RED probe on GND and BLACK probe on L7260 without charger.
Put it then in volt mode and measure PIN 23&21 with the charger plugged in.

Can you list up all EN pins? Voltages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is responsible for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_GH3</SIGNAL> and charging. 
I don't think it is faulty because you have PPBUS 8,4V
For charging it has to communicate with the SMC and the battery. If it can't communicate there is something wrong with the data lines (Page42) or current sense resistors (Pins 17,18,27,28) but first things first.
Make sure all your S5 Rails come up then take care of the data lines!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message:
The reason duke asked you to remove <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> is because this is what sits between the enable signal and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. If <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> is fucked and shorting to ground, it will pull that enable signal to ground as well. We are pulling off <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> as a way to isolate where the issue is. 

We have one of two issues.

1) <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is being CREATED, but shorted to ground by defective <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>(replace <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> as solution)
2) <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is not being created at all(investigate why <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is missing as solution)

Measure <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> without <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> here.

You should follow the advice, but also ask in your head, [I]why is duke asking me to do this? [/I]If you do this you will catch up with our reasoning and troubleshooting methods far faster than if you just follow what we say! Nothing will "happen" when <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> is removed because <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> being removed removes the path between the 3.3v rail enable signal and the chip responsible for 3.3v creation. This advice is not intended as a fix, but rather, as a troubleshooting tactic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won`t power up
threads.message: Powering it up without <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> may also cause everything to fry. Without <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> there is nothing to control the FETS and they can pass full PPBUS voltage to 3V or 5V bus. This thing is now fucked.
